andylovemath: Don’t give up. Meds are silly but when taken rigorously, they allow a better life because they make psychotherapy more efficient. erinsenge: This is exactly what I needed to hear right now. This is exactly the conversation I had with my psychiatrist today. carrie_banks: It’s so easy to feel discouraged and focus on just wishing you didn’t have depression. maryeyke: Make sure it is dye free! That red dude looks chemically coated like candy for kids. Which has actually destroyed my 16 year old son’s joie de vivre. WTF?! ange_who33: I myself am Bipolar and my meds have made me better. I take both an ant-depressant and mood stabilizer. If I skip a day I’m almost immediately back to the person I don’t want to be. shellyboo28: I take 8 pills a day for my bipolar depression and anxiety. It’s made me gain about 60 lbs, one gives me migraines, hot flashes (like walking out in a T-shirt in 30 degree weather), raises my blood pressure and pulse... just to make a few... but I take them bc of people like you who are brave enough to share your life with us and how I can share in good days... that motivates me to know I just have to keep going... funny you post this today bc I literally just got home from Xmas shopping where I was triggered by an object and went into full blown panic attack... I got thru it and was able to drive home but I survived it as scaring it the images in my head were I survived it... now I’m in my safe space and you just reminded me of that hope that better days will come along with the bad... thank you 💕

suzyroyle: Yes to all of this. I’ve been there. Progress isn’t linear (I ask myself “why the fuck not?” OFTEN.) I’m also impressed you were able to do as much as you did in this state. That right there is huge progress. 👊🏻

maggiemason: Yes! The path to even finding help and medication that works is a whole fucking hero’s quest. You are getting it done, as ever.
cdmass: Thanks for sharing. My wife, @purely_nora, sent this to me. As a bipolar-I male who has gone through 16 years of guess and check, I can 100% relate. It’s scary. Will it work? How long will it work for before I inevitably build a tolerance to the medication? Scary shit. Im happily medicated now, and have been on a new regime for 7 months (I’ve lost count what attempt this was - over a dozen). And guess what? I feel the best I have EVER felt. No manic episodes, no debilitating depression. Finally able to live life like a “normal” human being, addiction free going on 3 years, be present with friends and family, and have a newfound sense of humility. Wouldn’t trade my path to where I am today for anything. 👏🏻🥂❤️💯
barrettmommy: If your adult acne med is anything like Accutane, know that those drugs can have a huge impact on mental illness. I’ve known several fellow ladies (myself included) who used it & had exponentially increased anxiety/depression symptoms while using it. On a level I hadn’t experienced before being on it & I’ve been diagnosed & managing my mental health since my teens. Just wanted to share!
welwythn: This is beautiful. Thank you for your honesty.
kauffmanfarah: It’s awesome that you’re putting yourself first, whatever that looks like, including taking medicine. I take medicine every day to keep depression and anxiety to a minimum. Taking medicine for depression and anxiety when you need it is the same as my sister taking insulin. We all do what we need to do, in order to survive and to thrive. You are awesome. Know that.

saramarietexas: Someone once told me, upon being given my first anti-depressant, “it’s temporary. You are a strong and brilliant woman. You have a beautiful brain and heart and are being a spokesperson for so many people who are still terrified to speak to their struggle, so thank you for speaking your truth and bringing light to the darkness of depression. 💕
jnweaver75: My generalized anxiety, panic attacks, and OCD have a really really really flared so badly here recently. Along with PTSD. I’ve had so much go on the past several years and I had it somewhat under control but now it is crazy. I have been in therapy for Jay’s maybe a year and a half finally with someone who helps me. She’s amazing. Today she told me she would be out of town for three weeks. This is a tough time in my life as my brother passed away three years ago and also his birthday is on Christmas Eve. I take care of both of my parents. I’m also a single mother. On top of that I have crazy heart clips that drive me nuts and of course all the lovely things that come along with anxiety and stress. I work so hard. I meditate I pray I exercise eat well but sometimes it still tries to get the best of me. Sometimes I just have to give it to God and just get in the car and go and do. Sometimes though I feel like I want to lie Down in the floor and curl up in a ball and someone read my hair and tell me it will be OK. Kudos to you for taking care of yourself and putting yourself out there and being Rall for all of us. I hope you have a merry Christmas I hope you feel much better on your medication and I am rooting for you and behind you all the way! We are not alone. 💋🙏🏻💞🙌🏻💜
